VLIB Function Reference

Bhattacharya Distance

Introduction and Use Cases

Bhattacharya distance is a popular measure of the similarity between two discrete probability distribution functions.

Specification

Function

This function accepts as input two arrays, p and q, of size N containing the discrete probability distributions. It returns the Bhattacharya distance, B, between p and q as a 32-bit unsigned integer as defined in the following equation: 
     B = sqrt(1- SUM((sqrt(p(i)*q(i))))) , for all 0 < i < N ,SUM stands for summation.

Variants

This functionality is available in two variants:
  • Unsigned 16-bit input and 32-bit output (VLIB_bhattacharyaDistance_U32)
  • Floating point 32-bit input and output (VLIB_bhattacharyaDistance_F32)

Inputs


    Parameter   Description                                                         U32         F32
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    *X          Pointer to array containing first probability distribution        (UQ16.0)      F32
    *Y          Pointer to array containing second probability distribution       (UQ16.0)      F32
     N          Number of elements in the probability distributions               (UQ32.0)    (UQ32.0)
    *D          Pointer to variable to store the computed Bhattacharya Distance   (UQ32.0)      F32

Notes

  • All arrays should be double-word aligned.
  • Bhattacharya distance is defined on probability distribution functions. This implies that the elements in X and Y should sum to 1, respectively.
  • There should be a minimum of four elements in X and Y.

APIS

  • VLIB_bhattacharyaDistance_U32
  • VLIB_bhattacharyaDistance_F32
